pullRequest.body:
Redefine the BoundedOrder and Lattice on `Fin (n + 1)` so that they are defined for `Fin n`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: @YaelDillies
Don't forget to adhere to the PR title convention
I have removed the extra lemmas which I sensed might cause controversy, to focus on the minor change at the core of the PR.
Actually you're missing `top_eq_rev_zero`. Do we have `rev_top : rev top = bot` and `rev_bot : rev bot = top`?

I have a feeling we don't, I think I have them in one of my projects. But we do have that it's order reversing I think so maybe we do actually. Anyway, I can certainly add this.

Of course, I could add a Fin.last' n defined by being rev 0, but that seems... confusing to have.
We could probably have a "rev 0 = last n" currently! Would we then also need top_eq_last? Not sure.
I think all those lemmas are worth having
Great, I'll get them in.
Added. (I also substitued a proof which I couldn't resist, it was extremely undergolfed given we literally have the result in std.)

### PR summary [628b6cf514](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9814/commits/628b6cf51420f6c46513b140aff44760e96968fd)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ rev_bot`
`+ rev_last_eq_bot`
`+ rev_top`
`+ rev_zero_eq_top`
`+ val_rev_zero`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

Thanks!

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9682657069/job/26716184767)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9682657069/job/26716184410)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion exact âŸ¨fun h => âŸ¨âŠ¥, âŠ¤, hâŸ© , fun h => haveI := h; _root_.bot_ne_topâŸ© ```
Remind me why we can't generalize `last` instead?
It's harder because in Std. We would need to upstream `NeZero`. Certainly this information should be recorded somewhere in this file

I had a go at generalising it and it turned out to be somewhat annoying to find precisely the right definition. We might also want to think about adjusting the definition of `Fin.ofNat'`, also. But essentially you are going to want to use either `Nat.pred` or `Fin.pred` in some way. Or use `rev` as I have used here.
I think there's also an argument that an updated `Fin.last` should not take an argument (it should just come from its type).
I'm not sure I see the point in this lemma, given the proof
I think you are probably right. I think there probably is a use for `zero_ne_last` though (for `Fin.pred` and `Fin.castPred` purposes).
I have removed this.

There ought to be a version elsewhere that says
`(âŠ¥ : X) â‰  âŠ¤ â†” NonTrivial X`
We have `bot_ne_top`, but we don't seem to have an `iff` version?
We have `subsingleton_iff_bot_eq_top` but I am not sure we have `nontrivial_iff_bot_ne_top`.
I have removed this.
That's just `Subsingleton.elim`, right?
It is, but it seemed useful to have the special case? Also I don't think this depends on the subsingleton result.
I have removed this.
Could you leave a comment explaining the asymmetry between those two lemmas?

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem rev_bot [NeZero n] : rev (âŠ¥ : Fin n) = âŠ¤ := rfl
@[simp] theorem rev_top [NeZero n] : rev (âŠ¤ : Fin n) = âŠ¥ := rev_rev _
```

```suggestion
`[NeZero n]` whereas `last n` is of type `Fin (n + 1)`. To address this properly would
```

```suggestion
theorem val_rev_zero' [NeZero n] : ((rev 0 : Fin n) : â„•) = n.pred := rfl
```

Don't you think you should only have the latter and make it simp?
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem val_rev_zero [NeZero n] : ((rev 0 : Fin n) : â„•) = n.pred := rfl
```

```suggestion
require a change to the standard library, defining `NeZero n` and thus re-defining `last n`
(and possibly make its argument implicit) as `rev 0`, of type `Fin n`. As we can see from these
lemmas, this would be definitionally equal to the existing definition. -/
```
